repository.corpname: Washington and Lee University, James G. Leyburn Library Special Collections and Archives

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: Washington and Lee University

did.langmaterial: The materials in this collection are mostly in English.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This record group contains materials created by individual academic departments.

p.a: View materials from this collection online via W&L's Digital Archive

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The materials from Washington and Lee University Special Collections are made available for use in research, teaching, and private study, pursuant to U.S. Copyright law. The user assumes full responsibility for any use of the materials, including but not limited to, infringement of copyright and publication rights of reproduced materials. Any materials used should be fully credited with the source. Permission for publication of this material, in part or in full, must be secured with the Head of Special Collections.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research use.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Preferred citation: [Identification of item], Record Group 9: Academic Departments, Special Collections and Archives, James G. Leyburn Library, Washington and Lee University, Lexington, VA.
In some cases the citation format may vary. Please contact Special Collections staff to verify the appropriate format.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Booklet for the exhibit The strangest Fruit by Vincent Valdez, which was on display in Staniar Gallery from April 27-May 29, 2015. It includes essays by various scholars about the widespread, institutionalized racism experienced by many of color in America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Transcript includes exit interviews with forty graduating African American students at Washington and Lee University in 1997 conducted by Jennifer Ashworth, the administrative assistant in the History Department.

did.unittitle: History 269, Prof. Ted DeLaney, Washington and Lee University Spring Term Class Postings from two college Civil Rights Classes on a tour of the South.
The First Freedom Ride: Journey of Reconciliation, 1947
Voting Rights Movement in Selma, Alabama
Violent Action in Lowndes Country and the Deep South States
The Media and the Freedom Riders
Who says you can't go home?
Freedom Ride: Drawbacks and Concerns that were Overlooked
Diversity within the Movement for Racial Equality
Sheyann Webb and Rachel West Nelson
The Tragedy of a Forgotten Past
Medgar Evers and the Rights Movement
From Emmett Till to Tamir Rice: Black Boys, Racial Violence, and the Media
"this is not a method for cowards...."
Properly Honoring the Legacy of Dr. King
The Sixteenth Street Baptist Church and the Civil Rights Movement
Jim Crow and the Struggle for Freedom
The Ongoing Fight for Civil Rights

origination.corpname: Herbert Reichner Verlag

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This German journal has The First Printing in Virginia by Douglas C. McMurtie tipped into the center of the volume. The back of the insert says 'Designed, composed in Linotype Baskerville, and printed by C. Harold Lauck at the Journalism Laboratory Press of Washington and Lee University, Lexington, Virginia, U. S. A., for Philobiblon, a Book-Collector's Magazine published by Herbert Reicher, Vienna, Austria. December 1935'
